name: ferromanganese production, high-coal, 74.5% Mn | ferromanganese, high-coal, 74.5% Mn | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/7875/documentation

The module describes the consumption of ferromanganese in Europe in 1995. It is designed for the use of the metal as alloying element. This module does not consider secondary sources of manganese. Process data is taken mainly from a material flow analysis for the consumption of chromium in Germany. Results are used as a proxy for the European situation. This module may be used as proxy for the silicomanganese production;[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]

The activity starts with the reception of manganese concentrate at the smelter gate.

The module includes the reduction to high-carbon ferromanganese. No secondary production considered, since secondary manganese is recycled to the foundries and has to be inventoried in the respective module, i. e. when casting the final rawmaterial in the steel production.
category: C:Manufacturing/24:Manufacture of basic metals/241:Manufacture of basic iron and steel/2410:Manufacture of basic iron and steel

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This module relates to the consumption in Europe, although the import mix for Germany is chosen.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The ore is processed in blast furnaces (20%), electric arc furnaces without flux (27%), electric arc furnaces with calcareous flux (53%).
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: see Geography and Technology This dataset has been copied from an original dataset covering the geography RER. The uncertainty has been adjusted accordingly.

exchanges.description:
A number of manganese-containing ferroalloys are manufactured which are used largely in the mild steel, foundry, and stainless steel industries. The principal manganese ferroalloys and their typical components are high-carbon ferromanganese (78% manganese, 7% carbon, balance mostly iron) and silicomanganese (66% manganese, 17% silicon, 2% carbon). 

Uses: See "ISIC 2420" - pdf-document on the dedicated talk page of ecoinvent (www.ecoinvent.org/documentation), in section "Manganese".

This resulting amount was odelled, based on "ISIC 2420" - pdf-document on the dedicated talk page of ecoinvent (www.ecoinvent.org/documentation) (See part: Regarding "ferromanganese production, high-coal, 74.5% Mn, RER 2003" dataset).
EcoSpold01Location=RER

flow.name: NMVOC, non-methane volatile organic compounds
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
Estimation: Average water use for European ferrochrome production of 20 m3 (10 m3 - 30 m3) per tonne is chosen as an approximation, resulting in 10 m3 of effluents (volume of process water). In order to be considered as unpolluted sewage, the effluent has to be treated in a communal waste-water treatment plant, a process whose burden is not accounted for in this dataset. Emissions to water are inventoried separately.

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=CH
Calculated value: The total inert waste generation results from the addition of wet scrubber dust (0.0253 kg/t) and dry cake (0.3 kg/t).

Wet scrubber dust is modelled, based on “ISIC 2420” - pdf-document on the dedicated talk page of ecoinvent (www.ecoinvent.org/documentation) (part: Regarding “ferromanganese production, high-coal, 74.5% Mn, RER 2003” dataset).

Dry cake is Modelled, based on “ISIC 2420” - pdf-document on the dedicated talk page of ecoinvent (www.ecoinvent.org/documentation) (part: Regarding “ferromanganese production, high-coal, 74.5% Mn, RER 2003” dataset).

Further references: Adelhardt W. and Saiger H. (1999) Stoffmengenflüsse und Energiebedarf bei der Gewinnung ausgewählter mineralischer Rohstoffe; Teilstudie Mangan. In: Geologisches Jahrbuch, Vol. Sonderhefte SH 8. Bundesanstalt für Geowissenschaften und Rohstoffe, Hannover. ISBN 3-510-95830-6.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value: 10 m3 of effluents t of ferromanganese are generated. Based on that, 7.5 kg of dissolved solids / t (this being the average of reported values) are produced, which after wastewater treatment end up in 0.375 kg/t (see unpolluted sewage exchange for information regarding the wastewater treatment).

Estimation: Data corresponds to ferrochromium production.

Estimation: Data corresponds to ferrochromium production.

exchanges.description: 46% Fe in siderite; 25% Fe in ore; Calculated value. The composition of the reference product is taken from version 2 report 10 “Life cycle inventory of metals” table 3.4 “types of ferromagnesium and their general composition” and assumed to be:  74.5% Mn, 7.5% C, 1% Si (assumed from value reported in table 3.4 is  <1.25%). The remaining (17%) is assumed to be Fe. The required input of “Iron, 46% in ore, 25% in crude ore, in ground” is calculated in proportion to the input of manganese, which is of 0.613kg of manganese for 1 kg of manganese concentration. The input of magnesium concentrate to the dataset is of 2.33kg.

exchanges.description:
The amount of coke required is 0.45 kg (Classen et al. 2009, Tab. 5.5 page 399). The net calorific value of hard coal coke is 28.6 MJ/kg. The scaling by 0.8 is to account for the fact that the inventory of the dataset supplying the heat was divided by 0.8 for the update to version 3.0 of the database.


References:
Classen M., Althaus H.-J., Blaser S., Tuchschmid M., Jungbluth N., Doka G., Faist Emmenegger M. and Scharnhorst W. (2009) Life Cycle Inventories of Metals. Final report ecoinvent data v2.1, No 10. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH, Online-Version under: www.ecoinvent.ch
